awd_titl_txt: CIBR: New Methods for Multi-Omics Data Analysis and Genome Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists today are faced with a deluge of single- and multi-omics data, and of sequenced genomes. Although these data hold great promise, they present sizable analysis challenges: data analysis is a major bottleneck to discovery from multi-omics technologies and genome sequencing. Examples of multi-omics data include transcriptomics data plus metabolomics data, reaction flux measurements plus transcriptomics data, and transcriptomics data plus proteomics data. Pathway Tools (PTools) is an extensive bioinformatics software system whose capabilities include genome informatics, pathway informatics, omics data analysis, and metabolic modeling. PTools accelerates the research and education of the thousands of scientists and students who have downloaded it, and for the thousands of scientists and students who access PTools-powered websites. As genomes are the foundation of modern biology, the benefits to society of improved genome analysis and data management are extensive, including studies of soil microbes for agriculture; studies of animal pathogens for animal health; metabolic engineering of microbes for greener fuels and chemicals; studies of microbes to enhance human foods; studies of invasive microbial species; studies of wastewater treatment; and studies of microbes involved in global chemical cycles, including those that will be affected by climate change.

With this funding, significant extensions to PTools for both single-omics and multi-omics data analysis will be developed. The goal of the project is to provide tools for multi-omics data analysis that will enable simultaneous visualization of up to four types of omics data on three different pathway-related diagrams. These visualization-based analysis tools will enable faster, deeper understanding of omics datasets than is possible with current tools. A key insight for the latter tool is to create software that maps multiple input omics data dimensions to intuitively navigable pathway and whole-metabolic network diagrams that are tightly coupled to multi-omics scoring tools, enabling scientists to interpret these data in a functional context. During the award period, two robust new versions of the software will be release per year, and its user community supported through user outreach and training, answering questions, and fixing bugs. To access P-tools, visit http://bioinformatics.ai.sri.com/ptools/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Scientists are faced with a deluge of omics data (such as measurements of the expression of thousands of genes simultaneously, and of sequenced genomes. Although these data hold great promise, they present sizable analysis challenges to the discipline of bioinformatics: Data analysis is a major bottleneck to discovery from multi-omics technologies and genome sequencing. Developing computational methods to extract new understanding from complex multi-omics data presents significant intellectual challenges. Examples of multi-omics data include transcriptomics data plus metabolomics data, reaction flux measurements plus transcriptomics data, and transcriptomics data plus proteomics data.

We have developed a new tool for multi-omics data analysis that enables simultaneous visualization of up to four types of omics data on organism-specific metabolic network diagrams in a manner similar to visualization of traffic data using Google Maps. This software maps multiple input omics data dimensions to intuitively navigable whole-metabolic network diagrams, enabling scientists to interpret these data in a functional context. The tool is unique in its ability to (1) display rich multi-omics datasets containing multiple time points; (2) animate the display of those datasets with semantic zooming; and (3) automatically generate the metabolic network diagrams that provide the underlying framework for these displays, in contrast to other tools that require the network diagrams to be drawn manually. Thus, our tool can be applied immediately to tens of thousands of organisms. Overall, this tool will enable faster, more comprehensive analyses of multi-omics datasets than was previously possible.

Our new Genome Explorer genome browser utilizes the latest web technologies to speed scientist’s abilities to understand, navigate, and exploit genome data.  Understanding genome information depends to a large degree on understanding spatial relationships between elements within a genome, and the ability to navigate to regions of interest within a genome.  Thus, by providing more efficient navigation abilities within our new genome browser, and by depicting genome elements using graphical styles that are more familiar to scientists, we have made genome data more accessible to scientists.

The Pathway Tools software (PTools) accelerates science for the 16,380 scientists who have licensed it and for thousands of scientists who use the 17 websites powered by PTools. Those websites were spared the huge expense of developing their own genome/metabolic website software.

The explosion in the use of single- and multi-omics technologies within the life sciences has created a massive data analysis problem that our omics-data analysis tools will make a substantial contribution toward solving. The software enables researchers from diverse biological disciplines to more effectively translate omics data into actionable knowledge that can be applied to benefit human society and advance human health, agriculture, and a sustainable environment. Benefits to society of PTools’ highly integrated capacities for metabolic reconstruction, metabolic modeling, multi-omics data analysis, and genome analysis are extremely broad and include studies of soil microbes for agriculture, animal pathogens for animal health, metabolic engineering of microbes for greener fuels and chemicals, microbes to improve human foods, and microbes involved in global chemical cycles that will be affected by climate change.

 


Last Modified: 01/10/2025
Modified by: Peter D Karp

Image
  • Depiction of the E. coli K-12 genome using Genome Explorer. The legend in the lower-left corner describes the graphical symbols for different genome elements.
    Peter Karp
    Public Domain
    Peter D Karp
    Genome Explorer Genome Browser
